patterns: How do I cope with anxiety
responses: Regular exercise, even just a 10-minute walk, can significantly reduce anxiety. Physical activity releases endorphins that improve mood and reduce tension.
Mindfulness meditation can help you stay present and reduce anxious thoughts about the future. Start with just 5 minutes daily and gradually increase.
Cognitive restructuring is helpful: identify negative thought patterns and challenge them with evidence. Ask yourself, 'What's the evidence for and against this thought?'
Let's try box breathing: inhale for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds, exhale for 4 seconds, hold for 4 seconds. Repeat this cycle 4 times.
Diaphragmatic breathing helps reduce anxiety. Place one hand on your chest and the other on your stomach. Breathe deeply so that your stomach pushes your hand out, not your chest.

Try alternate nostril breathing: Close your right nostril with your thumb, inhale through your left nostril, close your left nostril with your finger, release your thumb, exhale through your right nostril. Reverse and repeat.
Mindfulness is the practice of paying attention to the present moment without judgment. Start by focusing on your breath for 5 minutes daily.
A simple mindfulness exercise is mindful eating: focus completely on the experience of eating, noticing flavors, textures, and sensations without distraction.
For anxiety, try the STOP technique: Stop, Take a breath, Observe your thoughts and feelings, and Proceed with awareness. This brings you back to the present moment.

patterns: I can't sleep because of anxiety
How to sleep better with anxiety
responses: Create a consistent sleep schedule by going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, even on weekends. This helps regulate your body's internal clock.
Try a 'worry journal' before bed. Write down your concerns and a brief action plan for each. This helps get anxious thoughts out of your head.
Create a calming bedtime routine: dim the lights, avoid screens for an hour before bed, take a warm bath, or practice gentle stretching. This signals to your body it's time to sleep.

patterns: What to do during panic attack
responses: During a panic attack, focus on your breathing. Try breathing in for 4 counts and out for 6 counts. Remember that panic attacks are temporary and will pass.
Use the 5-4-3-2-1 technique: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste. This grounds you in the present.
Remind yourself that panic attacks, while frightening, are not dangerous. Your body's alarm system is misfiring. Continue slow, deep breathing and know this will pass in a few minutes.
